title: On the complexity of finding large odd induced subgraphs and odd coloringsWork supported by French projects DEMOGRAPH (ANR-16-CE40-0028), ESIGMA (ANR-17-CE23-0010), and ELIT (ANR-20-CE48-0008-01), the program â€œExploration Japon 2017â€ of the French embassy in Japan, and the JSPS KAKENHI grant number JP18K11157. An extended abstract of this article appeared in the Proceedings of the 46th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), volume 12301 of LNCS, pages 67-79, held online, June 2020. This article is permanently available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.06078.

sections.tight bounds:
In this section we provide two tight bounds concerning odd induced subgraphs and odd colorings. Namely, we first provide in TheoremÂ 5.1 a tight upper bound on the odd chromatic number in terms of tree-width, and then we provide in TheoremÂ 5.2 a tight lower bound on the size of a maximum odd induced subgraph for graphs that admit a join. For every graph GğºG with all components of even order we have that Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤ğ—ğ—â€‹(G)+1subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºğ—ğ—ğº1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq{\sf tw}(G)+1, and this bound is tight. Scott provedÂ [42, Corollary 3] that every graph GğºG with all components of even order admits a vertex partition such that every vertex
class induces a tree with all degrees odd. Consider such a vertex partition, and let Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} be the graph obtained from GğºG by contracting each of the trees to a single vertex. Since Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is a minor of GğºG, we have that ğ—ğ—â€‹(Gâ€²)â‰¤ğ—ğ—â€‹(G)ğ—ğ—superscriptğºâ€²ğ—ğ—ğº{\sf tw}(G^{\prime})\leq{\sf tw}(G). Now note that every proper vertex coloring of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} using qğ‘q colors can be lifted to a partition of Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) into qğ‘q odd induced subgraphs (in fact, odd induced forests). Indeed, with every color iğ‘–i of a proper qğ‘q-coloring of Vâ€‹(Gâ€²)ğ‘‰superscriptğºâ€²V(G^{\prime}) we associate an induced forest of GğºG defined by the union of the trees whose corresponding vertex in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is colored iğ‘–i; see FigÂ 6 for an example. Therefore, where we have used the well-known fact that the chromatic number of a graph is at most its tree-width plus oneÂ . To see that this bound it tight, consider a subdivided clique Knsuperscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘›K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ }, that is, the graph obtained from a clique on nğ‘›n vertices, with nâ‰¡0,3(mod4)ğ‘›0annotated3pmod4n\equiv 0,3\pmod{4}, by subdividing every edge once; see Fig.Â 7 for an example. Since no pair of original vertices of the clique can get the same color, we have that Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(Kn)=n=ğ—ğ—â€‹(Kn)+1subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ—ğ—superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘›1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ })=n={\sf tw}(K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ })+1. Let us mention some consequences of TheoremÂ 5.1. Hou et al.Â 7 define the following parameter. Let ğ’¢ksubscriptğ’¢ğ‘˜\mathcal{G}_{k} be the set of all graphs of treewidth at most kğ‘˜k without isolated vertices, and let ck=minGâˆˆğ’¢kâ¡ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)|Vâ€‹(G)|subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğºsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘˜ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºğ‘‰ğºc_{k}=\min_{G\in\mathcal{G}_{k}}\frac{{\sf mos}(G)}{|V(G)|}. InÂ 7 the authors prove that c2=2/5subscriptğ‘225c_{2}=2/5 and say that the best general lower bound is ckâ‰¥12â€‹k+2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜12ğ‘˜2c_{k}\geq\frac{1}{2k+2}, which follows from a result of ScottÂ . As an immediate corollary of TheoremÂ 5.1 it follows that ckâ‰¥1k+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜1c_{k}\geq\frac{1}{k+1}, which improves the lower bound by a factor two. As it is knownÂ 7 that, for kâˆˆğ‘˜delimited-[]4k\in, ckâ‰¤2k+3subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2ğ‘˜3c_{k}\leq\frac{2}{k+3}, our lower bound implies that 1/4â‰¤c3â‰¤1/314subscriptğ‘3131/4\leq c_{3}\leq 1/3 and 1/5â‰¤c4â‰¤2/715subscriptğ‘4271/5\leq c_{4}\leq 2/7. We now provide a lower bound on ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G) for every graph that admits a join. For every nğ‘›n-vertex graph GğºG that admits a join we have and this bound is tight even for cographs. Let V1,V2âŠ†Vâ€‹(G)subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2ğ‘‰ğºV_{1},V_{2}\subseteq V(G) define a join of GğºG. We proceed to define a coloring c:Vâ€‹(G)â†’:ğ‘â†’ğ‘‰ğºdelimited-[]3c:V(G)\to such that, for some iâˆˆğ‘–delimited-[]3i\in, Gâ€‹[câˆ’1â€‹(i)]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘1ğ‘–G[c^{-1}(i)] is an odd subgraph with the claimed order. We distinguish three cases according to the parities of nğ‘›n, |V1|subscriptğ‘‰1|V_{1}|, and |V2|subscriptğ‘‰2|V_{2}|. Case 1: nğ‘›n is even and both |V1|,|V2|subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2|V_{1}|,|V_{2}| are odd. Gallai proved (seeÂ ) that the vertex set of every graph GğºG can be partitioned into two sets A,Bğ´ğµA,B such that Gâ€‹[A]ğºdelimited-[]ğ´G[A] is odd and Gâ€‹[B]ğºdelimited-[]ğµG[B] is even. We apply this result to both Gâ€‹[V1]ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰1G[V_{1}] and Gâ€‹[V2]ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰2G[V_{2}], yielding four sets V1ğ–¾,V1ğ—ˆ,V2ğ–¾,V2ğ—ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰1ğ–¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰1ğ—ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰2ğ–¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰2ğ—ˆV_{1}^{{\sf e}},V_{1}^{{\sf o}},V_{2}^{{\sf e}},V_{2}^{{\sf o}} such that, for iâˆˆğ‘–delimited-[]2i\in, Vi=Viğ–¾âŠViğ—ˆsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–âŠsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ–¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ—ˆV_{i}=V_{i}^{{\sf e}}\uplus V_{i}^{{\sf o}}, Gâ€‹[Viğ–¾]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ–¾G[V_{i}^{{\sf e}}] is even, and Gâ€‹[Viğ—ˆ]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ—ˆG[V_{i}^{{\sf o}}] is odd. For iâˆˆğ‘–delimited-[]2i\in, the fact that Gâ€‹[Viğ—ˆ]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ—ˆG[V_{i}^{{\sf o}}] is odd implies that |Viğ—ˆ|superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ—ˆ|V_{i}^{{\sf o}}| is even, which in turn implies that |Viğ–¾|superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ–¾|V_{i}^{{\sf e}}| is odd since, by assumption, |Viğ–¾|+|Viğ—ˆ|=|Vi|superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ–¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ—ˆsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–|V_{i}^{{\sf e}}|+|V_{i}^{{\sf o}}|=|V_{i}| is odd. We define câˆ’1â€‹(1)=V1ğ–¾âˆªV2ğ–¾superscriptğ‘11superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰1ğ–¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰2ğ–¾c^{-1}(1)=V_{1}^{{\sf e}}\cup V_{2}^{{\sf e}}, câˆ’1â€‹(2)=V1ğ—ˆâˆªV2ğ—ˆsuperscriptğ‘12superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰1ğ—ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰2ğ—ˆc^{-1}(2)=V_{1}^{{\sf o}}\cup V_{2}^{{\sf o}}, and câˆ’1â€‹(3)=âˆ…superscriptğ‘13c^{-1}(3)=\emptyset. Since V1,V2â‰ âˆ…subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2V_{1},V_{2}\neq\emptyset as they define a join of GğºG, and both |V1|subscriptğ‘‰1|V_{1}| and |V2|subscriptğ‘‰2|V_{2}| are odd, it follows that, for iâˆˆğ‘–delimited-[]2i\in, Viğ–¾â‰ âˆ…superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ–¾V_{i}^{{\sf e}}\neq\emptyset. This implies that both Gâ€‹[câˆ’1â€‹(1)]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘11G[c^{-1}(1)] and Gâ€‹[câˆ’1â€‹(2)]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘12G[c^{-1}(2)] are odd, and therefore one of them has order at least n/2ğ‘›2n/2. Case 2: nğ‘›n is even and both |V1|,|V2|subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2|V_{1}|,|V_{2}| are even. Let v1âˆˆV1subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘‰1v_{1}\in V_{1} and v2âˆˆV2subscriptğ‘£2subscriptğ‘‰2v_{2}\in V_{2} be two arbitrary vertices. We define câ€‹(v1)=câ€‹(v2)=3ğ‘subscriptğ‘£1ğ‘subscriptğ‘£23c(v_{1})=c(v_{2})=3 and we apply CaseÂ 1 above to the graph Gâˆ’{v1,v2}ğºsubscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2G-\{v_{1},v_{2}\} with join given by V1âˆ–{v1}subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘£1V_{1}\setminus\{v_{1}\} and V2âˆ–{v2}subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘£2V_{2}\setminus\{v_{2}\}, obtaining two odd induced subgraphs of GğºG colored 1 and 2, one of which has order at least (nâˆ’2)/2ğ‘›22(n-2)/2. Note that Gâ€‹[câˆ’1â€‹(3)]ğºdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘13G[c^{-1}(3)] is also an odd subgraph (an edge). Case 3: nğ‘›n is odd. Assume without loss of generality that |V1|subscriptğ‘‰1|V_{1}| is even and |V2|subscriptğ‘‰2|V_{2}| is odd, and let v1âˆˆV1subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘‰1v_{1}\in V_{1} be an arbitrary vertex. We apply again CaseÂ 1 to the graph Gâˆ’{v1}ğºsubscriptğ‘£1G-\{v_{1}\} with join given by V1âˆ–{v1}subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘£1V_{1}\setminus\{v_{1}\} and V2subscriptğ‘‰2V_{2}, obtaining two odd induced subgraphs of GğºG, one of which has order at least (nâˆ’1)/2ğ‘›12(n-1)/2. Note that since nğ‘›n is odd, in this case Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) is not defined. Summarizing, we have proved that if nğ‘›n is even, then ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥nâˆ’22ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºğ‘›22{\sf mos}(G)\geq\frac{n-2}{2}, and that if nğ‘›n is odd, then ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥nâˆ’12ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºğ‘›12{\sf mos}(G)\geq\frac{n-1}{2}. Taking into account that an odd subgraph must have even order, both cases imply that, for every nğ‘›n, ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥2â‹…âŒˆnâˆ’24âŒ‰ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºâ‹…2ğ‘›24{\sf mos}(G)\geq 2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{n-2}{4}\right\rceil. Let us now see that this bound is tight for both even and odd values of nğ‘›n. For even nğ‘›n, consider the tripartite graph K2,2,2subscriptğ¾222K_{2,2,2}. It can be checked that this graph contains none of K4subscriptğ¾4K_{4}, K1,3subscriptğ¾13K_{1,3}, and 2â€‹K22subscriptğ¾22K_{2} (which are the only odd subgraphs on four vertices) as an induced subgraph, and therefore ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(K2,2,2)=2=2â‹…âŒˆ6âˆ’24âŒ‰ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œsubscriptğ¾2222â‹…2624{\sf mos}(K_{2,2,2})=2=2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{6-2}{4}\right\rceil. Finally, for odd nğ‘›n, consider C5+superscriptsubscriptğ¶5C_{5}^{+}, that is, the graph obtained from C5subscriptğ¶5C_{5} by adding (any) two vertex-disjoint chords. Again, it can be checked that this graph contains none of K4subscriptğ¾4K_{4}, K1,3subscriptğ¾13K_{1,3}, and 2â€‹K22subscriptğ¾22K_{2} as an induced subgraph, and therefore ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(C5+)=2=2â‹…âŒˆ5âˆ’24âŒ‰ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶52â‹…2524{\sf mos}(C_{5}^{+})=2=2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{5-2}{4}\right\rceil.
Note that both K2,2,2subscriptğ¾222K_{2,2,2} and C5+superscriptsubscriptğ¶5C_{5}^{+} are cographs; see Fig.Â 8. Determining a tight lower bound for cographs that are not necessarily connected remains open. The proof of CasesÂ 1 andÂ 2 of TheoremÂ 5.1 together with the fact that Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(K2,2,2)=3subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğ¾2223\chi_{{\sf odd}}(K_{2,2,2})=3 (since ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(K2,2,2)=2ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œsubscriptğ¾2222{\sf mos}(K_{2,2,2})=2) yield the following corollary. Let GğºG be a cograph with every connected component of even order. Then Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤3subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº3\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 3. Moreover, this bound is tight. Note that cographs can be equivalently defined as P4subscriptğ‘ƒ4P_{4}-free graphs. It is interesting to note that, in contrast to CorollaryÂ 1, P5subscriptğ‘ƒ5P_{5}-free graphs have unbounded odd chromatic number. Indeed, let Hnsubscriptğ»ğ‘›H_{n} be the graph obtained from the subdivided clique Knsuperscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘›K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ }, with nâ‰¡0,3(mod4)ğ‘›0annotated3pmod4n\equiv 0,3\pmod{4}, by adding an edge between each pair of original vertices of the clique. It can be checked that Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(Hn)â‰¥nsubscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘›\chi_{{\sf odd}}(H_{n})\geq n and, in fact, the proof of TheoremÂ 3.2 implies that Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(Hn)=nsubscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘›\chi_{{\sf odd}}(H_{n})=n. Note that Hnsubscriptğ»ğ‘›H_{n} is a split graph, hence split graphs have unbounded odd chromatic number.
